lesson.title_and_level: Upper-Intermediate - Saved by the Gong: Chemistry

sentence.idiomatic: When you buy a cellphone, how can you tell which ones are smuggled and which are legitimate?
I can tell just by rubbing whether it's real silk or artificial silk.

word.literal: to be or not to be

sentence.idiomatic: We don't know whether this painting is real. Let's ask an expert to come help us judge.
Don't worry, our products have to go through many tests before they leave the factory.
Implementation is the only standard for testing a truth.
Food safety is a very serious matter. The quality testing department must test very rigorously.
The river water is jade-green and clear. The pebbles at the river bottom are clearly visible.
Before the real facts of the situation are clear, a guess is only a guess.
We definitely must find some proof to clarify the the situation.
I'd rather be thirsty than drink such muddy, murky water.
This bottled beverage has become really murky, it's definitely not potable anymore.
The air in this area is really murky. When you go out for a bit, your nostrils get full of dirty black stuff.
During the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics, former gymnastics hero Li Ning lit the main torch.
When the birthday candles were lit, I shut my eyes and made a happy wish.
The rocket's launch realized our dreams, and ignited our enthusiasm.
To complete this week's work, we should break it into five stages.
Your last problem only has the result, with none of your steps. No wonder you lost points.
When you're pursuing a girl, there's no point to hurrying. You should follow a plan, going slowly step by step.
A certain kind of environment is necessary to produce a typhoon.
Using this kind of software, you can easily make interesting pictures.
Randomly generated passwords are relatively safe, but also rather difficult to remember.
Look, everyone. These four vials of gas hold hydrogen, oxygen, carbon monoxide, and carbon dioxide. But they aren't labeled, so how do we distinguish them?
Teacher, teacher! Oxygen can be tested with a glowing splint.
You can also use a burning splint. The oxygen will make the splint burn brighter and brighter.
Carbon dioxide makes clear limewater turn murky.
Carbon monoxide and hydrogen are combustible.
You all answered very well. Now let's plan out the steps of the experiment.
Test for oxygen first!
Test first for carbon dioxide!
OK, don't argue. Everyone, break into groups.
Chen Lei, what will you test for first?

word.literal: measure word for long slender things

sentence.idiomatic: Let's first test for carbon dioxide! Quick, get out four test tubes, and pour in the settled limewater.
This bottle has carbon dioxide!
Chen Lei, here you go, a glowing splint!
Oh, both of these bottles ignited. So, how will we know which one is hydrogen and which is carbon monoxide?
Don't rush, look at mine! OK, this one is carbon monoxide!
Teacher, we've figured out which is which!
Good. So let's ask Chen Lei to say a bit about the steps of his experiment.
First, use the settled limewater to test for carbon dioxide, then use the burning splint, then...ah...
Let's have Xu Xiaoting speak. Chen Lei is not very articulate, he can do it but can't talk about it.

The one that can make the wooden splint burn brighter and brighter is oxygen. The ones that ignited were hydrogen and carbon monoxide. Afterward, use the settled limewater again to test the gas produced by the burning. Because carbon monoxide produces carbon dioxide when burned.
Very good. Today's experiment was a big success. After class, please carefully fill in your experiment reports.
